citation.article-title: Propionibacterium australiense sp. nov. derived from granulumatous bovine lesions.

p.s: Description of Propionibacterium australiense sp. nov.
Propionibacterium australiense (aus.tral.i.ense, M.L neut. n., referring to Australia, the country where the bacterium was first recovered)
Bacterial cells are Gram-positive, asporogenic, pleomorphic rods, observed to be variable in length with occasional branching or slightly curved forms.
The bacterium upon initial isolation may require 5 days to grow, but will grow abundantly in 24â€“48 h growth on BHIA at 35EC under anaerobic atmosphere after repeated subculture.
Colonies after growth on BHIA are nonhaemoytic, cream coloured, shiny, rounded, convex and are not adherent to agar.
They are able to grow poorly in 5% CO2 atmosphere but grow best under strictly anaerobic conditions.
They grow well in PY with or without glucose supplementation but not in the presence of 20% bile.
They are catalase and oxidase negative, and non-motile.
Esculin is hydrolysed and nitrate reduced.
They are negative for indole, gelatin hydrolysis, starch hydrolysis, urease production, meat digestion and CAMP or reverse CAMP reaction.
No gas is observed after glucose fermentation.
All strains ferment adonitol, fructose, glucose and inositol.
No strain ferments amygdalin, arabinose, cellibiose, erythritol, glycogen, maltose, melezitose, rhamnose, sorbitol, starch, sucrose, trehalose and xylose.
The reactions for galactose, lactose, mannitol, mannose, raffinose, ribose and salicin are variable.
Products of glucose fermentation included acetic, propionic and succinic acids.
CFA composition was of the branched-chain or saturated type.
Mesodiaminopimelic acid was found in the cell wall.
The type strain 98A072 has been deposited as ATCC BAA- 264T and CCUG 46075T with characteristics as shown in Table 2.
Nearly full sequence of the 16S rRNA gene derived from the type strain has been deposited in Genbank with accession no. AF225962.
The bacterium was isolated from granulomatous lesions from bovines in Queensland, Australia.
